awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Shape-Based Imputation and Estimation of Fragmented, Noisy Curves with Application to the Reconstruction of Fossil Bovid Teeth
awd_abstract_narration:
Statistical analysis of shape data is relevant to a wide array of fields including biology, anthropology, chemistry, and medicine, to name just a few. Current methods for analyzing shape data generally focus on shapes that are fully observed. This project will develop methods for analyzing shapes that are only partially observed. Traditional missing data techniques are not applicable in the shape setting when 1) shapes are defined by functions and 2) shape-preserving transformations (e.g. translation, rotation, scaling, re-parameterization, etc.) must be accounted for. This project will formalize and harness this perspective for data obtained from fragmentary fossil tooth images of the Family Bovidae (antelopes and buffaloes) as partially observed curves, representing the outlines of imaged objects, possibly with measurement error. The resulting taxonomic identifications will generate more robust estimates of the ecologically sensitive bovids. These improved estimates, in turn, afford novel insight into the paleoenvironmental context of early human evolution.
 
The main goal of this project is to develop statistical methods for the analysis of partially observed shapes (i.e., fragmented curves). This goal will be accomplished via two different approaches: 1) developing computational methods for imputing a fragmented curve by matching and completing it based on a template or donor curve obtained from a sample of fully observed curves, and 2) developing Bayesian model-based methods for estimation and classification of the shape of a noisy, fragmented curve using an empirical prior on the overall shape of the curve. Both approaches will be built using Riemannian geometric tools for shape analysis that ensure proper invariance to shape preserving transformations including translation, scaling (when appropriate), rotation, and re-parameterization. These methods will be developed with the motivating application of the analysis and taxonomic classification of fractured and complete fossil teeth from the Family Bovidae. By generating a proxy for paleoenvironmental conditions, the project seeks to advance our understanding of the relationship between environmental change and hominin evolution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Statistical analysis of shape data plays an important role in many scientific domains including computer vision, biology, medical imaging, biometrics, bioinformatics and anthropology, among others. Shape is a property of an object that remains unchanged under the following shape-preserving transformations: translation, rescaling, rotation and reparameterization. A major methodological challenge arises when shape data is only partially observed, i.e., fragmented curves. Traditional missing data techniques are not applicable in the shape setting since shapes are defined by functions and the aforementioned shape-preserving transformations must be accounted for. Through this collaborative project, we developed algorithmic and Bayesian model-based approaches for completion or imputation of partially observed shapes. Importantly, the developed algorithms and models appropriately account for nuisance transformations and allow for uncertainty quantification for the fragmented part, and potentially also noisy observed part, of the underlying shape. As a secondary goal, we used the completed shapes in classification tasks.

The motivation for the methodological advances in this project stems from work done by biological anthropologists who are interested in classifying bovid tooth fossils for the purposes of reconstructing past environments in the interest of studying early human behavior. Broken bovid teeth are often identified only to the taxonomic Family or Tribe, if they are considered at all. If the broken bovid teeth can be identified even just to genus level, more bovid teeth can be used in the analyses and the paleoenvironments of our early human ancestors could be reconstructed more precisely. Complete fossil teeth were represented as closed curves, while fractured ones were represented as open curves. Our algorithmic approaches for imputing the missing portion of a fractured fossil tooth relied on shape information from completely observed donor teeth or their summary, e.g., the average shape. The developed Bayesian models incorporated shape information from completely observed fossil teeth via appropriate prior models. Beyond anthropology, the methods are applicable in many different contexts including computer vision (objects observed with occlusions) and medicine (boundaries of organs that are difficult to identify due to image resolution and contrast).

We mentored multiple graduate students who received training in statistical shape analysis, missing data methods, statistics on manifolds and functional data analysis. The project allowed these students to travel to multiple conferences and present their research on these topics. This advanced their graduate studies in many ways by providing an opportunity to interact with senior researchers in our field, receiving feedback on their research accomplishments and improving their written and oral communication skills. We additionally offered graduate level courses that incorporated parts of this project’s research agenda. Finally, we have been active in software and data dissemination to the broader research community.
